prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: G357.96-0.16
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Source Group I.
In addition to CO(J=2-1), H(30) alpha, CH3OH class I v t=0 8(-1, 8)-7(0,7), CH3OH class II v t=0 1(1,0)-0(0,0) and SiO(5-4), CH3OH class II v t=0 5(1,4)-4(2,2) at 216.9456 GHz can be observed simultaneously with SiO (Baseband-2).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We propose to survey molecular lines of CO, SiO, CH3OH and hydrogen recombination line H30 alpha at band 6. Except for target sources, most of the technical justification section are common for all of four Science Goals. Target sources are listed in the Scientific justification section (Table 1). Tracking center positions are coincident with the 44 GHz methanol maser features. Because distributions of maser features are compact with a typical size of 1500 AU (or 0.3" at 5 kpc; see Figure 1) and our target sources are massive star-forming regions possibly harboring massive star clusters, we need to resolve line emissions with 0.3" beam to identify powering sources of target masers. Thus, we propose observations with the suitable spatial resolution in a standard mode of cycle 3, 0.3" at 220 GHz. We select band 6 to cover as large field of view as possible and to achieve sufficiently high sensitivities/resolution (band 3 and 4 are excluded for this reason). We here estimate observing time based on flux densities/brightness temperatures of our target lines at 220 GHz. Estimated brightness temperatures of CO, CH3OH, and H30 alpha lines are typically around 2-5 K (e.g. Cyganowski et al. 2011, Zhang et al. 2014) and that of SiO line are 1 K (Zinchenko et al. 2011). The brightness temperature of 1 K corresponds to 2 mJy/beam with the beam size of 0.3". A frequency resolution around 1.3km/s is enough to resolve the velocities width (a few km/s) of CO and CH3OH lines. For SiO and H30 alpha lines, we can average 4 channels to enhance the signal-to-noise ratio because of their larger line-widths. We will achieve signal-to-noise ratio of around 3 (rms=2.5 mJy and 1.25 mJy) with a frequency resolution of 1.3 km/s and 5.2 km/s for CO/CH3OH and SiO/H30 alpha lines, respectively. These values are enough to resolve typical line-widths of massive star-forming regions. In summary, we need 18.14 minutes of on-source time for each pointing. Such observations with a high sensitivity and a high spatial resolution would request unrealistically long observing time for other arrays, usually one target per full track. Therefore, ALMA is indispensable for our science goals of proposed systematic survey project.

Typical line-widths of our target lines are 1-5 km/s for CO and CH3OH (e.g. Cyganowski et al. 2011) and more than 10 km/s for SiO and H30 alpha (Zinchenko et al. 2012, Zhang et al. 2013). Thus, we set the spectral resolution of 1.3 km/s to resolve these lines. For the SiO and H30 alpha lines, we will average four channels to enhance signal-to-noise ratio to detect weak emissions.

We focus on investigating the local physical environment where bright and compact 44 GHz methanol maser spots are emitted.The 44 GHz methanol maser spots are clustering with separations of at least a few hundred arcseconds (see Figure 1 in Scientific justification). Thus, we request the angular resolution of 0.3.
For the largest angular scale, 44 GHz methanol masers are known to be distributed over wide area of 0.1--0.5 pc (Menten 1991; Kurtz et al. 2004; Cyganowski et al. 2009), thus, we need a field of view as large as possible to cover whole of possible maser distributions, 28" or 0.7 pc for 5 kpc sources at band 6. This size is almost same as a beam size of an ALMA 12 m antenna.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: G10.34-0.14
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Source Group II.
In addition to CO(J=2-1), H(30) alpha, CH3OH class I v t=0 8(-1, 8)-7(0,7), CH3OH class II v t=0 1(1,0)-0(0,0) and SiO(5-4), CH3OH class II v t=0 5(1,4)-4(2,2) at 216.9456 GHz can be observed simultaneously with SiO (Baseband-2).

Source Group IV.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose high-resolution molecular line observations toward 44 GHz class I CH3OH maser sources to investigate the physical environment of shocked regions traced by 44 GHz class I CH3OH masers. Previous interferometric studies of Class I CH3OH masers suggests that the masers trace the shocked gas in the dynamical structures in star forming region, such as outflows, HII regions, and the cloud-cloud collision. However, the detailed kinematics and physical environment of the region where the masers arise are still unclear due to the scarcity of high-resolution data of shock tracers and masers. From 2013, we started observations of 15 MYSOs associated with 44GHz CH3OH masers with KaVA, and this sample will give a unique chance to study the detailed information of physical environment of the shocked regions where maser arises by comparing high-resolution observations of shock tracers to VLBI images of masers. We will observe CO and H30a to trace the outflows and HII regions, SiO to trace shocked molecular gas. to compare the physical properties of shocked region with each maser features observed with VLBI, the high-spatial resolution and the high-sensitivity of ALMA is inevitable.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2013.1.01103.S,'Molecular line observation toward 44 GHz methanol maser sources detected with KaVA', Mikyoung Kim 2013.1.00701.S,'ALMA and KaVA Survey of MYSOs associated with multiple masers', Naoko Matsumoto
